Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about a broad range of topics in reproductive biology, but did not have a chance to delve into them deeply.
I gained a broad understanding of the reproductive system.
everything about reproduction
I learned how to condense lecture information into what would be actually tested.  I learned to switch between many different professors' teaching styles.
Learned a lot about the basics of reproductive biology, which was very relevant to my life and my future career goals as a premed student.
Many insights into reproduction and my own body and reproduction that are and in the future will be very useful to know.

I am not an MCDB major, but if you are already competent in Biology and thinking of getting a science credit, this is a great option! I learned how to tackle more in-depth material while getting an overall well-rounded view of the biology of reproduction of humans, which is honestly super relevant!

I learned all about reproduction, from the development of both the male and female reproductive systems, to the fertilization of an egg and development of an embryo, how these functions are regulated, and what can affect them.  I also learned about medical technologies used to treat defects in reproduction and some of the history behind our current understanding of the reproductive system.
I learned so much about reproduction that was interesting and very applicable!
So I love this  class! I learned so much about the beauty of human reproduction and the consequences of many of our actions. Wish I could take again!
Learned reproduction and reproductive systems, from conception to puberty
I learned about the implications of pituitary and steroid hormones (like estrogens and androgens), as well as some other themes such as contraception, placenta and menopause.
I learned about the human body, hormones, and reproductive anatomy.
This course taught me so many cool things about reproductive biology!
I learned about sexual differentiation, sex hormones, and the other aspects of reproductive function.
Kind of a messy course with bad overlap between lectures
It was a great class and I learnt a lot - I have never taken a reproduction class before and I found it very interesting.
Lots of cool information about reproductive biology in this course. I really appreciated the inclusion of ethics and social consequences Refreshing in an McDb course.
nothing
I gained much knowledge of the reproductive system and hormones.
Learned some biology that I have never encountered in any either MCDB classes and got an interesting clinical perspective on a lot of the topics.
I learned a lot about the different mechanisms underlying the maintenance of a successful pregnancy.
We learned about many different aspects of human reproduction, like the reproductive tracts, ethics, contraception, diseases, etc. Very interesting topics.
I learned a lot about how human pregnancy works (which I didn't know at all before) and the intricate way that our bodies develop and are controlled by our hormones.

I really enjoyed this course. It was a sort of survey course of the many facet of reproductive biology, and I developed a newfound interest in human biology that I had never explored previously. I feel like I have developed new understandings of such a wide variety of biological processes, and while the survey nature of the course precludes depth into some topics, I feel that we were able to still get somewhat deep into some areas, and the broad nature allows me to then study selected concepts further through other coursework or on my own. This was my favorite course of the semester!

I learned a lot about the female and reproductive system, including its development , and transition into a fully functional reproductive system. I learned about the different techniques of IVF, along with the ethics associated with it.
A basic understanding of reprobio!

You learn all about the human reproductive system, both male and female but with a particular focus on female for obvious reasons. It covers everything from the hormones involved to the organs, environmental factors, and the ethics of IVF, etc.

The strengths of this course are that experts in each field are brought in to talk to students about topics they are extremely well-versed in. This brought variety and knowledge of the latest research to the course and I appreciated it.
The strength is directly related to the weakness of this course: it often felt disjointed -- there was no connection between one lecture and the next, making it hard to follow sometimes. It could be improved if there was more coordination between the professors who teach each topic to make sure none is covered twice and nothing important is skipped.
Also, I thought Prof Lubna Pal was extremely disrespectful to students who asked questions. The way she taught was extremely confusing and ineffective.
Though I enjoyed learning from a variety of clinicians, the lectures as a whole sometimes felt disjointed.

strengths: many different experts in particular subjects, rotation of profs makes it feel fresh every time, slides are posted so you can focus on understanding rather than copying words down
weakness: many profs also means slight inconsistencies in lecturing (some would rush through material too fast for you to write any extra info down, while others took their time and went way over the end of the class, which sucks for people who have a class right after)
Very good class - not overly mentally taxing but incredibly interesting.

The class was pretty relaxed and not a lot of work, but I still felt that I learned a lot and got a lot out of it. However, the quality of the lecturers ranged considerably and many of them were poor speakers and not very engaging. I also wished that there was a bit less overlap in some of the lectures.
A strength of this course is its many different topics and different professors with expertise on each topic.
Tests used vocabulary and language often not mentioned in class, but is assumed from outside knowledge.

Strengths: You learn so much in the course, but it isn't stressful because there aren't that many assignments.  Also because most lectures are done by guest speakers, mostly OB/GYNs from the Med School, they are often experts in the topic they present and have conducted research on it themselves.
Weaknesses: Some of the lecturers seemed to be so focused on the scientific aspects and data on various aspects of reproduction that they lost sight of the social factors at play.

I like that all the different lecturers are given apparently the same instructions on how to structure their presentations- with clear pages referring to the topics about to be presented and overall summaries at the end of every lecture.
Strengths are the material is so interesting! I kind of liked having different professors because it kept things interesting, but at times it was frustrating because they would repeat material.

Strength: coolest content, great lectures who were experts and involved in the Med School, felt like taking a Medical school course

Weakness: The correct lecture slides were not always posted on Canvas before the actual lecture. Disconnect between lecturers and course instructors/TAs, MCDB majors had to attend journal club discussions but not sure if these factor into the overall grade?

Strengths - physician lecturers, TA's, section
Weaknesses - some questions on the midterm could be reworded to be clearer

This course could be improved by removing some of the redundancy. Since all of the lecturers were (in a way) "guest" lecturers, they often repeated what we had already learned without realizing it. That said, I really enjoyed hearing from a variety of professors and doctors about their work. Everyone was a specialist in his or her field of study, and it showed.
Some of the lectures were really strong. Others were unengaging and dull. Select guest lecturers with more care?
Since there is a different lecturer every time (which I think is great) sometimes the exams did a poor job of reflecting what we learned in the lectures

The variety of professors are both a strength and a weakness. Some of them are super strong and engaging... some not so much. For me it really worked and kept things interesting, but some others might not enjoy this format.

A strength is that the TAs were very helpful. A weakness was that it was a bit disorganized, in terms of that the slides posted online didn't match the ones in lecture, and similar concepts were repeated many times. More detailed explorations on fewer topics could have been helpful, or coordination between lecturers.
It's an easy STEM class and lowkey with exams but it's really eclectic material with really bad and really good lectures. Really hit or miss.

Weaknesses - confusing with overlap between lectures
Everything else was great

Lectures too disjointed, weird not having 1 main professor, felt like some lecturers didn't know what we had learned before so we sometimes relearned some things, some lecture slides were kind of unorganized, hard to adjust to teaching styles of so many different lecturers

Some lecturers were great and others were terrible. I think its cool to have different people come in, but make sure theyre not constantly repeating the same material. Also maybe reevaluate the quality of different lecturers. 

There was occasionally reference to marriage and some gender stereotypes that I think have no place in a biology course. But overall it did this less than some other biology courses Ive taken
get rid of it

Overall strong course. Perhaps have the lecturer place more clear emphasis on broader themes that are relevant for the exam. Sometimes presentations were excessively detailed and difficult to conceptualize.

Strengths include the addressing of the most important reproductive biology concepts and the different perspectives of the lecturers. Weaknesses included constantly repeated information and posted powerpoints not being the same as the lecturers' presentations.

Quality of test questions was poor. For each test, there were several questions that had to be removed from the final tally due to excessive confusion. Many questions were vague and ambiguous, requiring the TFs to clarify them to the whole lecture during exam periods.

The course is slightly disorganized and the lecturers vary in quality, from excellent to pretty subpar. Overall though, the material is interesting and the course is not rigorous in the slightest (essentially zero work outside of exam studying). The exams are fifty multiple choice and a few short answer questions and while easy, the questions are sometimes ambiguous and test irrelevant minute details that are of little importance to the overall subject matter. The exams were more like high school memorization/regurgitation multiple choice tests that failed to assess real conceptual understanding and critical thinking and unlike any other college-level biology assessment that I've taken.

Having three non-cumulative exams and no final was a major plus. The course material was always quite interesting, but the guest lecturers greatly varied in their teaching style, which often made it difficult to take copious lecture notes. Also, the slides tended to be very long, so it would be helpful if lecturers could mention what would be best to focus on when preparing for the exam.

I think having a different lecturer was interesting, but it would be nice if they communicated among each other so that they knew what we had already been taught. For example, some lecturers just repeated things we already knew, or brought up things we were yet to learn.

The survey nature of the course allows students to find areas that speak to them in a huge field of specialties. Additionally, the introduction to such as wide range of faculty members allows students to contact faculty specializing in areas they find particularly interesting. I did so, and I was even able to shadow the faculty member in the lab/clinic and see the concepts from class come to life! Some of the professors are more engaging than others, and sometimes the information from one lecture would contradict information from another, but aside from maybe filtering out some of the less engaging lecturers and syncing up the content a bit better, I think the course has little to improve upon!
A bit disorganized, but overall a pretty good class.

The material is very interesting, but the exams are really unfair. You never know what to expect. Also, having different lectures is difficult because some days there were powerpoints and some other days they were not. Exams were mostly based on the powerpoints, which sometimes were not fully covered.
Other assignments to help grade students, a lot to just rely on multiple choice.

Every lecture is essentially taught by a guest lecturer who is a practicing specialist in that field -- which is both a strength and a weakness of the class. On the one hand, it's really cool that you're being taught by people who really know their shit, but on the other, the course overall is a bit disjointed. There is often a lot of overlap between lectures because they don't know what other lecturers have covered. It would help if the professor or TA went through the guest lecture notes beforehand and let them know what has already been covered, and to what extent. Yeah, it would be extra work on their part but what else are they doing?
Yes
Yes because I learned a lot of science in a stress-free environment.
absolutely; low workload outside of class, extremely interesting material (just make sure you study - the curve can be brutal on the exams)

I would definitely recommend this class.  You can really choose how engaged you want to be and go into depth learning the material or just glide over and learn only what is needed for the exams.  GO TO SECTION before the exams, very helpful for more targeted studying.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student if they need the credit or if they are looking for a relatively easy elective. It's definitely not the most entertaining class to sit through, but the workload is incredibly low and the tests are easy. I learned a fair amount from preparing for the tests even though the lectures were not super engaging and not very well integrated (all guest lectures w/ huge range in quality).
I would 100% recommend this course, it was very interesting content that is applicable to our own lives.
Yes, I would recommend because there is very little work. Tests are MC and non-cumulative, so only three times during the whole semester do you really need to hunker-down.
Absolutely.  An interesting and low-stress class.  You'll learn so much without too much worrying about your grade.

This is an MCDB course taught from a medical perspective, looking at reproduction in all its manifestations in the human body, with plenty of mention of disease and treatment options for patients. It is one of the only MCDB courses structured in this way, and that alone makes it worth taking.

The evaluations are very fair, given the sheer amount of material you are expected to master. It is definitely not a gut, but it is also structured in such a way that non-majors can benefit from the SC credit. There are major and non-major discussion sections (the latter being optional), and the staff have a genuine desire to see everyone master the material.

Taking this course was truly a great experience.
Yes! Pretty easy and very interesting MCDB class.
Yes!! Take it!!
I would definitely recommend this to another student! You learn so much about both the science and social issues behind reproductive biology.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I feel like I learned a lot, but there was very little pressure or stress.
Yes, but not unless you have a solid bio foundation and actually are willing to study a lot.
Yes, very interesting!
Yes! Very interesting, and a relatively easy MCDB.
I would recommend this class to any student who has an interest in reproductive development. You learn a lot.
Kind of. Not really.
Yes definitely - very interesting and lots of different topics covered
only if you want a class to credit d but not really care about, it feels hard to be really passionate about this class but it was fine I guess, some things were definitely interesting
Not great structure but Interesting material! The class was chill with a small workload but a lot of reward because of the material
DEFINITELY
Absolutely! A relatively stress-free and engaging way to check off a science credit. Definitely worth taking.
Yes, I would recommend this course to those interested in learning more about the reproductive system without having too much stress.
Absolutely take if you need a science credit
I think this is a great class and the material is relevant/important for everyone to know; however, it is rather difficult if you're not a bio major
Do not take this if you are not in the major/it is required.

Easy, interesting class for science/biology majors. Might be slightly more challenging for students without a background in biology but certainly manageable if you are looking to get that science credit!
Yes, this is a great course to fulfill one of the upper level Bio requirements for the Neuroscience track of the Psychology major.

It was a good class, with really interesting material. The tests are all multiple choice and reminded me of high school bio exams (a lot of memorization and recall of facts). Although the material was easy to understand, the tests sometimes asked really small details. I would say take it if you're even remotely interested in the topic.

This class is not only on the lighter side as far as workload, but it is also super interesting and gives great exposure to so many facets of reproductive biology. I learned so much, and I had fun doing it! This is one of my favorite courses I've taken at Yale!

I regret taking this class for a letter grade--this would have been the ultimate Credit/D class. 3 midterms, no final, and they're all multiple choice. This semester, everyone seemed to score very high and in a narrow range, so I don't think that grading will be particularly lenient. Great class for casually learning about human reproduction (especially about the female reproductive system) from a series of different lecturers.
It is one of the easier Biology courses, but the exams are tricky so be careful.
A good basis, interesting material with some good professors. But I would recommend just using a credit/d.

It's a good/easy fifth class. The 3 exams that your grade is based on were about 50 multiple choice questions pulled from the lecture slides. But some of the questions were very very specific and required you to know specific statistics that didn't always seem very pertinent or essential to your understanding of the material. But personally, I found it to be too disorganized and the lecturers were either hit or miss in how engaging they were, and I don't feel like I am walking away with a ton of knowledge.
